questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: A patient had a femur fracture for which internal fixation was done. Two days later, the patient developed sudden onset shortness of breath with low grade fever. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fat embolism

 

FAT EMBOLISM

  • Fracture Femur with Breathlessness after 48 hours – think of fat embolism!
  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome (FES) reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow.
  • Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Salient Features:
    • Presence of fat globules in pulmonary circulation.
    • Precipitated by physical trauma such as fracture of long bones, soft tissue trauma, and burns.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Clinical signs and symptoms develop after a asymptomatic latent period of about 12 - 48 hours.
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      • Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea.
      • Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation.
      • Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder.
  • Diagnosis:
    • FES is distinct from the presence of fat emboli.
    • Symptoms usually occur 1-3 days after a traumatic injury and are predominantly pulmonary (shortness of breath, hypoxemia), neurological (agitation, delirium, or coma), dermatological (petechial rash), and hematological (anemia, low platelets).
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood.
    • If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation.
    • Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg.
    • O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumothorax. A pneumothorax is a collection of air outside the lung but within the pleural cavity. It occurs when air accumulates between the parietal and visceral pleurae inside the chest. The air accumulation can apply pressure on the lung and make it collapse. Causes of traumatic pneumothorax are penetrating or blunt trauma, rib fracture, diving or flying. While it can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur specifically after femur fracture fixation unless there was a procedure complication.

 

Option B. Pleural effusion. Pleural effusion is the accumulation of fluid in between the parietal and visceral pleura, called the pleural cavity. It can occur by itself or can be the result of surrounding parenchymal disease like infection, malignancy, or inflammatory conditions. While it can cause respiratory symptoms, it is less likely to occur suddenly after femur fracture fixation unless there are other complicating factors.

 

Option D. Congestive cardiac failure. Congestive heart failure (CHF) is a complex clinical syndrome characterized by inefficient myocardial performance, resulting in compromised blood supply to the body. CHF results from any disorder that impairs ventricular filling or ejection of blood to the systemic circulation. Patients usually present with fatigue and dyspnea, reduced exercise tolerance, and systemic or pulmonary congestion. While congestive heart failure can cause shortness of breath, it is less likely to occur suddenly after a femur fracture fixation unless the patient has pre-existing heart conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fat embolism is the most common complication of femur fracture.
  • It usually presents 48 hours after the injury with breathlessness and low grade fever.
  • The patient  remains asymptomatic in the initial 12-48 hours.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.
  • Medullary cavity, Metaphysical tumour

 

 

  • Most common tumour of bones of hand and feet
  •  5% premalignant
  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome. There are multiple enchondromas all over the body.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith (Calcified superficial veins) = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment: Extended Curettage + bone grafting

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple brown tumor. It has been reported that 2-5% patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have brown tumor (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Bone brown tumor secondary to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is very rare, which is caused by massive secretion of PTH. First, a large amount of bone calcium is mobilized into blood, resulting in fibrous tissue hyperplasia in bone and leaky hemorrhage. Then, macrophage reactive hyperplasia resulted in phagocytosis of red blood cells and a large amount of hemosiderin is produced, thereby forming a brown nodule. The lesions are usually multiple, most commonly seen in ribs, clavicle, pelvis, long bones and mandibles while others are rare. The radiograph of brown tumor is often characterized by osteoporosis, thinning of cortical bone and multiple localized cystic bone destruction.

 

 

Option C. Multiple osteophytic growth. Osteophytes are cartilage-capped bony proliferations that most commonly develop at the margins of a synovial joint as a response to articular cartilage damage, as seen very commonly in degenerative joint disease. Central osteophytes can develop from cartilage lesions within a joint. They are considered a hallmark of osteoarthritis. Osteophytes may be confused with syndesmophytes and enthesophytes. Small osteophytes are sometimes referred to as osteophytic lipping.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows multiple enchondromas in the hand.

choices.text: Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound, with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as type 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

 

GUSTILO AND ANDERSON CLASSIFICATION FOR OPEN FRACTURE

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm. This is the description of Type I of open fracture where the wound is clean and of <1cm length.  

 

Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury. This is the description of Type II of open fracture where the wound length is >1cm with mild soft tissue damage or skin flap or avulsion.

 

Option C. Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required. This is the description of Type IIIA of the open fracture where there is an adequate periosteal coverage present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIIB of the open fracture is the open wound with significant periosteal stripping.
  • It requires secondary bone coverage and procedures like skin grafting or flap.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The provided image indicates an upward displacement of the clavicle, accompanied by a noticeable gap between the clavicle and the acromion.
  • This suggests potential injuries to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

 

ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury typically occurs due to a fall onto the acromion.
  • Stability of the AC joint is dependent upon both the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligaments.
  • An acromioclavicular joint separation occurs when the clavicle separates from the scapula.
  • It is commonly caused by a fall directly on the ‘point’ of the shoulder or by a direct blow received in a contact sport.
  • AC Joint separation is almost always the result of a sudden, traumatic event that can be attributed to a specific incident or action.
  • The two most common causes are either a direct blow to the shoulder (seen in football, rugby, or hockey), or a fall on to an outstretched hand (after falling off a bicycle).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the joint
    • Pain on movement of the arm
    • Depending on the grade, a bump may be present on the top of the shoulder where the clavicle ends
    • The joint may be very unstable
  • It is classified into type 1 to 6 by Rockwood classification according to the severity of the injury and position of the displaced bones.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment according to the grades include:
    • Type I-III: Conservative management with velpeau bandage. The bandage pushes the lateral end of shoulder downwards and the arm upwards, thus maintaining the reduction.
    • Type IV-VI: Open reduction and internal fixation

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Coracoacromial ligament. Coracoacromial ligament originates from the medial border of the acromion and attaches to the lateral border of the coracoid process. This ligament forms a part of the coracoacromial arch and provides support to the humeral head. Coracoacromial ligament injury is mostly related to trauma or clavicular fracture and isolated injury to the coracoacromial ligament is rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture

 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS

 

  • This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications. 
  • Most common elbow fractures – 50-70%
  • Mechanism:
    • The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. 
    • As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles. 
  • Pathoanatomy:
    • The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles. 
  • Types:
    • A supracondylar fracture may be of extension or flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment. 
    • The extension type is the commoner (98%) of the two. 
    • In this, the distal fragment is extended (tilted backwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
    • In the flexion type, the distal fragment is flexed (tilted forwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and cast
    • If conservative management fails or if fracture is displaced, closed reduction and K-wire fixation is done.
  • Complications:
    • Malunion – most common 
    • Posteromedial displacement develops cubitus varus/gunstock deformity
    • Nerve injury: Anterior interosseous nerve most commonly injured followed by median, radial and ulnar nerves – transient neuropraxia occurs 
    • Vessel injury: Brachial artery 
    • Volkmann’s ischemia and compartment syndrome 
    • Elbow stiffness 
    • Myositis ossificans 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. It is commonly associated with dinner fork deformity. It is treated successfully with a hand-shaking cast. Finger stiffness is the most common complication. Malunion is the 2nd most common complication, leading to dinner fork deformity. Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of sudeck’s dystrophy in the upper limb. 

 

 

Option B. Lateral epicondyle fracture. Lateral humeral condyle fractures are the second most commonly encountered elbow fractures after supracondylar fractures in the pediatric age group. These fractures are intra-articular and are prone to displacement owing to the attachment of the forearm extensor muscles on the lateral condyle. Due to this, they can produce various complications, including elbow deformity, if not appropriately managed. Displaced fractures are at a higher risk of non-union. Malunion, cubitus varus, avascular necrosis, and post-operative infection are recognized complications following surgery. The most common mechanism is a fall on the outstretched hand with the elbow in extension and the forearm in supination. Fractures with <2mm displacement can have conservative treatment. The indications of surgery are fracture displacement >2 mm and articular surface incongruency. Closed reduction and percutaneous fixation are options.

 

 

Option C. Medial epicondyle fracture. A medial epicondyle fracture is an avulsion injury of the attachment of the common flexors of the forearm. The injury is usually extra-articular but can be sometimes associated with an elbow dislocation. Medial epicondyle fractures are common and account for 10% of all elbow fractures in children. They occur between the ages of 7-15 years. They are usually a result from an avulsion injury caused by a valgus stress at the elbow and contraction of the flexor muscles. Potential complications include medial elbow instability and nonunion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a gunstock deformity i.e., cubitus varus deformity of the elbow after malunion of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

 

  • The image shown in the question is of high-stepping gait, where the foot drops due to common peroneal nerve injury and while walking, the foot slaps on the ground.

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is one of the two major branches of the sciatic nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor:
      • Peroneus longus
      • Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation are:
    • Motor:
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal webspace
  • The nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck.
  • The most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology. It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe webspace.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • A patient with weakened or paralyzed dorsiflexors may ambulate with a high steppage gait to prevent dragging of toes on the ground.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Waddling gait. Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, like in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture of the hip joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients have difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase. This waddling gait pattern can also be caused when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. 

 

 

Option C. Circumduction gait. Also called as Hemiplegic gait, circumduction gait is most commonly seen in stroke. The patient stands with unilateral weakness on the affected side with arm flexed, adducted and internally rotated. Leg on the same side is in extension with plantar flexion of the foot and toes. While walking, the patient hold their arm to one side and drags the affected leg in semi-circle or circumduction due to weakness of the distal muscles (foot drop) and extensor hypertonia in the lower limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: Which method of measurement of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

 

  • This X-ray of spine shows lateral curvature (scoliosis) and angle marked is for its measurement – Cobb’s angle.

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

  • Most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kite’s angle. Kite’s angle or talocalcaneal angle is the angle between the lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneus measured on weight bearing foot radiograph. This angle varies depending on the position of the calcaneus under the talus and the stiffness of the foot ligaments. Measurement: midtalar line should pass through/just medial to the base of 1st metatarsal and the mid-calcaneal line should pass through the base of 4th metatarsal. In hindfoot varus, the talocalcaneal angle is < 25⁰; in hindfoot valgus, it is > 40⁰; while in a normal foot, it is 25-40⁰.

 

 

Option C. Bohler’s angle. Tuber angle of Bohler (Tuber-joint angle) is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. It is formed between a line drawn from highest points of anterior process of the calcaneus and highest point of posterior facet, and a line drawn tangentially to the superior edge of the calcaneal tuberosity. It is normally 20-40 degrees. Flattening/Reduction/Reversal of this angle indicates that the weight-bearing posterior facet has collapsed (intra-articular fracture) or Degree of proximal displacement of the tuberosity (intra-articular and extra-articular fracture both).

 

 

Option D. Gissane angle. Also known as critical angle of Gissane, it is used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures. It is formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus. Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95-105 degree. It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.

questions.text: X-ray of 12-year-old boy shown below find the most likely cause of the abnormality? (AIIMS 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rickets

 

The wrist X-ray shows signs of cupping and fraying at the metaphyses, which are characteristic features of rickets. Rickets results from inadequate mineralization of bone, affecting growth plates and leading to deformities. These radiological signs, along with thickening and widening of the growth plates and bowing of the diaphysis, are indicative of rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scaphoid fracture - This typically shows a fracture line through the scaphoid bone, not metaphyseal changes.

 

Option B. Colles’ fracture - This is characterized by a fracture of the distal radius with dorsal displacement, not metaphyseal cupping and fraying.

 

Option C. Osteoporosis - This condition involves decreased bone density but does not present with specific metaphyseal changes seen in rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rickets, caused by inadequate bone mineralization, is characterized by X-ray findings such as thickening and widening of growth plates, cupping of the metaphysis, and sometimes bowing of the diaphysis.

choices.text: Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip.
Vascular injury is more common in anterior hip dislocation.
Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior.
In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation.

questions.text: Mark incorrect option: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury more common in anterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

 

  • “Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip” – this statement is incorrect. 
  • In posterior hip dislocations, the sciatic nerve is at significant risk of injury. This is the most common nerve injury associated with hip dislocations.
  • In anterior hip dislocations, the femoral nerve or obturator nerve can be injured, but these are generally less common than sciatic nerve injury in posterior dislocations.
  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

questions.text: Most common joint involved in septic arthritis is:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially, there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then, Arthritis develops. Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis, only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and pathology:
    • Hematogenous route of infection is most common in all age groups
    • Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
       
  • Diagnosis:
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swelling.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint fluid helps to confirm the diagnosis by culture and also helps to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Order of investigations done: X-ray followed by MRI, then Aspiration.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
       
  • Septic arthritis with negative cultures: Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and associates criterion) – 5 out of 6 must be present
    1. > 38.3°C temperature
    2. Swelling of suspected joint
    3. Pain in joint that increases with movement
    4. Systemic symptoms
    5. No other pathologic process
    6. Satisfactory response to antibiotics therapy
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis until proven otherwise.
    • Knee: Most commonly affected joint; position is flexion
    • Hip: Position is flexion, abduction and external rotation.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule), surgical drainage (decompression), synovectomy and antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral).
    • Non-operative treatment is not considered as cartilage destruction occurs very rapidly and can cause permanent joint destruction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hip. Infections that can affect the hip are primarily either an infection of the bone i.e., osteomyelitis, or an infection of the joint i.e., septic arthritis. 

 

Option C. Shoulder. Infection of the shoulder joint is rare. It may occur after total shoulder replacement. The most common bacteria responsible for the infection are Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Propionibacterium acnes.

 

Option D. Elbow. Elbow joint infection may occur due to infected or septic arthritis, septic joint, infection after elbow surgery or after elbow replacement, bursal infection, soft tissue infection or cellulitis. 

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common joint involved in septic arthritis is the knee joint, followed by the hip joint.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male with Marfanoid habitus presents with sharp chest pain and sudden onset dyspnea. Chest X-ray was performed and is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pneumothorax

Explanation:

The given CXR shows the presence of pneumothorax, which represents air in the pleural space. 

DIAGNOSIS: Right pneumothorax
MEDIASTINAL SHIFT: Contralateral
MOST SENSITIVE IX: CT scan
MOST SENSITIVE X-RAY: Expiratory X ray

Other Options:

Option A. Pulmonary embolism on a CXR shows enlarged pulmonary artery (Fleischer’s sign and Palla’ sign).

Option B. Hydropneumothorax - concurrent presence of a pneumothorax and pleural effusion. On Chest X-ray air-fluid level is seen. 

Option D. Aortic dissection will present with mediastinal widening and will be detected in CECT. 

Educational Objective:

Pneumothorax is characterized by the presence of air in the pleural space and can be identified on a chest X-ray by a clear line indicating the separation of the lung from the chest wall, with absent lung markings in the affected area. This diagnosis is particularly concerning in individuals with Marfan syndrome due to their increased vulnerability to spontaneous pneumothorax.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the tumor shown in the radiograph? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Epiphyseal

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (Osteoclastoma):

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology:
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 30% malignant transformation. This is incorrect. Pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.

 

Option C. Ground glass opacity is diagnostic. This is incorrect. Ground glass opacity of the bone is seen in fibrous dysplasia.

 

Option D. Radiotherapy is the treatment. This is incorrect. The mainstay of treatment of GCT is curettage and stripping of the cavity. More aggressive tumors are treated by excision and bone grafting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Giant cell tumors are epiphyseal tumors of the long bones.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.

 

 

Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

questions.text:
True statements about fracture shaft of femur: (AIIMS MAY 2019)

 

  1. More commonly in elderly.
  2. Easily managed with Gallow’s traction in elderly.
  3. Associated with pulmonary complications.
  4. Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. c & d are correct

 

FRACTURE SHAFT FEMUR

 

  • Men are more likely to sustain a fracture between the ages of 15 to 35, while women begin to show a steady increase starting at age 60.
  • Men are more likely to sustain fracture from automobile accidents or other high-energy mechanisms.
  • Women are more likely to sustain an fracture from ground-level falls.
  • Automobile accidents are more prevalent in the younger population, while ground-level falls are more common in the elderly population, which is attributed to osteoporosis.
  • Treatment:

 

 

a. Management Plan of Fracture Shaft Femur in Adults: 

  1. Interlock intramedullary nailing currently is considered to be the treatment of choice for most femoral shaft fractures.
  2. External fixator is used in open fractures (open injuries).
  3. Delayed union is treated by dynamization of nail (removal of proximal or distal screws or both) and bone grafting.
  4. Non-union is treated by exchange nailing (i.e. introduction of large diameter reamed interlocking nail) and bone grafting.

 

b. Management Plan in children:

  1. Gallow’s traction: < 2 years of age and traction weight < 2 kg of weight can be used.
  2. Immediate or early spica casting is the treatment of choice in children <5 years of age for femoral fractures with < 2–3 cm of initial shortening, and stable fracture pattern.
  3. Femoral fractures with > 2-3 cm of shortening or marked instability, high probability of slipping of reduction and tight thigh swelling in 6 months to 5 years age group, who cannot be reduced with immediate spica casting, require 3-10 days of skin or skeletal traction before casting.
  4. Fixation by enders intramedullary flexible rods and plating can be used in children with multiple trauma, head injury, vascular compromise, floating knee injuries or multiple fracture, preferably in children > 6 years of age.

 

  • Complications:
    • Postoperative complications include fat emboli syndrome, pulmonary embolism, infection, osteomyelitis, malunion, nonunion, and hip and knee pain.
    • Nerve injuries are common and can be due to positioning as well as iatrogenic injury. Pudendal nerve injuries occur from positioning patients with a perineal post. The sciatic nerve can suffer injury in retrograde nailing with excessive traction of the lower extremity or surgical instruments. 
    • Vascular injury to the DFA or SFA can occur after penetration with instruments or implants.
    • Intraoperative fractures may occur, especially of the greater trochanter, the knee.
    • Malrotation is one of the most significant complications. Malrotation of greater than 14 degrees from neutral can alter gait mechanics and efficiency. Patients cope better with internal than with external malalignment.
    • Nonunion is a failure of the fracture to heal or lack of signs of healing for six months.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Femoral shaft fractures are more commonly seen in young males of age 15-35 years.
  • It is easily managed with intramedullary nailing in elderly.
  • It is most commonly associated with pulmonary complications like pulmonary embolism.
  • Intramedullary nailing is gold standard for management in adult patients.

questions.text: The last symptoms to develop in compartment syndrome is: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulselessness

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.

  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).

  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.

  • Clinical Features:

  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.

  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign.

  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis. 

  • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.

  • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Paralysis and Pulselessness are considered late and ominous signs, indicating severe and irreversible tissue damage. 
  • Paralysis and pulselessness signifies that the condition has progressed significantly, indicating permanent injury.
  • Pulselessness generally represents a more critical and terminal stage of circulatory compromise.
  • It implies complete or near-complete cessation of blood flow, which is ultimately the most severe and final physiological sign of impending tissue death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain on passive stretch. Pain and resistance to the passive stretch is the first sign of the compartment syndrome. 

 

Option B. Paralysis. Paralysis occurs in the late stages of the syndrome due to involvement of the nerves. 

 

Option C. Pallor. Pallor appears in the late stages and indicates irreversible muscle and nerve ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise. 

  • While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.

questions.text: Theophylline was prescribed to a male patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The next day, he noticed that his urine output had increased. Which of the following receptors is responsible for the drug's action? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Adenosine A1

 

Theophylline is a methylxanthine drug that primarily acts as a nonselective adenosine receptor antagonist. By antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, theophylline can lead to diuresis or increased urine output. Adenosine normally promotes water reabsorption in the renal tubules, and its blockade by theophylline results in increased urine production. This mechanism is separate from its therapeutic action in COPD, which involves bronchodilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Interleukin-10: Interleukin-10 (IL-10) is an anti-inflammatory cytokine. It is not a direct target of theophylline. IL-10 plays a role in regulating immune responses, but it is not involved in the diuretic effect or the primary action of theophylline in COPD treatment.

 

Option B. Histone Deacetylase: Histone deacetylase (HDAC) is an enzyme involved in chromatin remodelling and gene expression regulation. While theophylline has been suggested to have some modulatory effects on HDAC, especially in the context of COPD and asthma, it is not the mechanism responsible for the increased urine output observed in the patient.

 

Option D. Beta 2 Adrenergic Receptors: While theophylline has mild bronchodilatory effects thought to be mediated through inhibition of phosphodiesterase (increasing cAMP levels in smooth muscle), leading to relaxation of bronchial smooth muscles, beta 2 adrenergic receptors are more specifically targeted by drugs like salbutamol. Theophylline's diuretic effect is not mediated through beta 2 adrenergic receptors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Theophylline increases urine output by antagonizing adenosine A1 receptors, leading to decreased water reabsorption in the renal tubules and resulting in diuresis.

questions.text: A trauma patient suffered a renal laceration with urine extravasation. He was managed conservatively. However, after a few days, he presented with a urinoma. The next best management for this patient would be? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureteral stenting

 

The patient in the given question has renal laceration with urine extravasation, which classifies as grade 4 renal injury.

 

Ureteral stenting is a minimally invasive procedure that can help alleviate the obstruction and promote urine drainage, reducing the risk of infection and other complications associated with urinomas

 

Ureteral stenting involves the placement of a stent into the ureter to facilitate drainage of urine from the renal pelvis to the bladder. In the context of a urinoma, this can help alleviate the obstruction or urine accumulation, providing relief and preventing further complications. It is similar to placement of CBD stent via ERCP in cystic duct leak.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Surgical Repair and Exploration: Surgical repair and exploration may be considered if there is a significant structural or anatomical issue contributing to the urinoma that cannot be resolved through less invasive methods.

 

Option C. Observation: Observation alone may not be sufficient if the urinoma is causing discomfort, pain, or complications. It's crucial to address the urinoma promptly.

 

Option D. Percutaneous Drainage: Percutaneous drainage may be an option, but ureteral stenting is a more specific approach for managing urinomas resulting from ureteral obstruction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A urinoma is a collection of urine that has leaked from the urinary tract and has accumulated outside its normal anatomical location. This condition typically occurs due to trauma, injury, or obstruction in the urinary system.

 

  1. Causes: Urinomas are usually caused by trauma, such as blunt abdominal or pelvic trauma, that leads to injury to the urinary collecting system. They can also result from urinary tract obstruction, infections, or surgical complications.
  2. Symptoms: Common symptoms of a urinoma may include abdominal or flank pain, fever, and swelling in the affected area. In some cases, urinomas may be asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging studies.
  3. Diagnosis: Diagnosis involves a combination of medical history, physical examination, and imaging studies, such as ultrasound, CT scans, or MRI, to visualize the urinoma and determine its size and location.

 

A persistent urinoma (a mass formed by encapsulated extravasated urine) should be managed with the placement of an internal ureteral stent.

 

Patients not cured by ureteral stenting may require percutaneous nephrostomy or transcutaneous drainage.

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable, but he had loss of sensation in the 1st webspace. What will be the next step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign
    • Order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
    • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm. The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
       
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are:
    • Impending tissue ischemia
    • When the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mm Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mm Hg).
       
  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.

 

Extra Edge:

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Reapply cast. Application of cast will further put pressure on the leg compartments. So, this treatment method will not help.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the pain on passive flexion is the first sign of compartment syndrome. Pulselessness is the late feature. So it is advised to measure the compartment pressure first.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: An athlete suffers a fracture as shown in the knee X-ray below. How is this fracture managed? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring

 

PATELLA FRACTURE TREATMENT

 

  • The image displays a displaced patellar fracture, and the treatment of choice is Tension Band Wiring.
  • Tension Band Wiring (TBW) is a surgical method to secure the bones in place which are subjected to tension forces.
  • Wires and Screws or Pins are used to create this tension band effect.
  • In two-part fracture of Patella, the pull of Quadriceps on the proximal fragment keeps them apart.
  • In the operation, first the fractured fragments are reduced, fixed with TBW and then the extensor retinacula are repaired.
  • TBW converts distractive forces into compressive forces.

 

 

  • In case if there is comminuted fracture where accurate reduction is not possible, patellectomy is done.
  • Tension band wiring is done using: 
    • Cancellous screws for fracture of Olecranon process
    • K-wires and stainless steel wires for fracture of Patella

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Tension band wiring is the gold standard treatment for the two-part patella fracture.

questions.text:
A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity.
  2. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis.
  3. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP.
  4. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV are correct

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis
      • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
         
  • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
    • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Usually DIP is not involved in and is not used for diagnosis but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
    • Lumbar Spine is usually spared.
       
  • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
  • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
       
  • Treatment:
    • Exercises to maintain muscle strength and joint mobility.
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoid therapy esp. in vasculitis.
    • Immunosuppressive therapy by leflunomide, DMARDs, methotrexate (drug of choice), anticytokine, etanercept, cyclosporine, infliximab, adalimumab, abatacept.

 

Other Options:

 

  • NSAIDs are anti-inflammatory drugs and not disease-modifying drugs. NSAIDs are used for symptomatic treatment in RA. They have few side effects but also have potential adverse effects like GI bleeding.
  • Bone erosion is a central feature of rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with disease severity and poor functional outcome. Erosion of periarticular cortical bone, the typical feature observed on plain radiographs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, results from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: A 25-year-old young male who was a tattoo artist was brought dead to the casualty under mysterious circumstances. His girlfriend reported he had a large tattoo on his right hand, but this was not found on examination. Which structure should be examined to get more idea of the same? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lymph nodes

 

The ink used for making a tattoo mark is transported through lymph to the regional lymph nodes. Thus, if there is natural / iatrogenic tattoo removal the lymph nodes must be examined.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver: The liver is involved in the detoxification and metabolism of substances, but it is not directly related to the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option C. Spleen: The spleen filters blood and is involved in immune responses, but it does not play a role in the transport or storage of tattoo ink.

 

Option D. Skin: The skin is the primary site where tattoos are applied. However, in the case of a removed tattoo, the skin may not provide useful information about the former presence of the tattoo.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Examining the regional lymph nodes can reveal traces of tattoo ink even if the tattoo itself is no longer visible on the skin, providing useful forensic evidence.

questions.text: A patient after a roadside trauma presented to the trauma center with severe pain in his left hip. On examination, the hip is extremely tender with limited range of motion. The patient is lying in the posture seen below. Which of the following deformities is present in the patient? (AIIMS 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior dislocation of the hip

 

The patient's limb is positioned in a flexed, abducted, and slightly externally rotated posture, which is indicative of an anterior hip dislocation.

 

“Anterior Dislocation of Hip: The leg lies externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed. It is not shortened because the attachment of the rectus femoris prevents the head from displacing upwards. Occasionally, the leg is abducted almost to a right angle. When viewed from the side, the anterior bulge of the dislocated head is unmistakable, especially when the head has moved anteriorly and superiorly. The prominent head is easy to feel, either anteriorly (superior type) or in the groin (inferior type).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Posterior dislocation of the hip - Typically presents with the limb internally rotated and adducted.

 

Option C. Inferior dislocation of the hip - Rare and presents differently, usually with the limb in a different position.

 

Option D. Central dislocation of the hip - Also rare, involves the femoral head being pushed through the acetabulum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anterior dislocation of the hip presents with the limb externally rotated, abducted, and slightly flexed, often following trauma such as a road accident

questions.text: Which is not a feature of 3rd nerve palsy? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Abduction limitation

 

This is not a feature of third nerve palsy. Abduction of the eye is controlled by the lateral rectus muscle, which is innervated by the sixth cranial nerve. Limitation in abduction is indicative of sixth nerve palsy, not third nerve palsy. In third nerve palsy, there would be a limitation of adduction (movement of the eye towards the nose) instead.

 

Other Options:

 

Third nerve palsy (oculomotor nerve palsy) presents with several characteristic features due to the loss of function of the muscles it innervates:

 

Option A. Pupil dilatation: The third cranial nerve carries parasympathetic fibers responsible for pupil constriction. Damage to this nerve results in unopposed sympathetic stimulation, leading to pupil dilatation (mydriasis).

 

Option B. Ptosis: The levator palpebrae superioris muscle, responsible for elevating the eyelid, is innervated by the third cranial nerve. Damage to this nerve causes ptosis (drooping of the eyelid).

 

Option C. Down and out eye: The unopposed action of the lateral rectus (innervated by the sixth cranial nerve) and the superior oblique (innervated by the fourth cranial nerve) results in the characteristic "down and out" position of the affected eye.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Third nerve palsy presents with pupil dilatation, ptosis, and a down and out eye. Abduction limitation is not a feature of third nerve palsy; it is seen in sixth nerve palsy.

questions.text: Identify the condition:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body)
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • This intraosseous abscess is related to subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.

 

 

  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma. Hemangioma of bone is a benign tumor that usually involves a vertebra or the skull and commonly is found as an incidental asymptomatic lesion.  They are slightly less commonly encountered in men (M:F = 0.7:1) and most commonly seen in the 5th decade of life but can occur at any age. These tumors are slow-growing and are most commonly asymptomatic unless they exert mass effect on sensitive structures, present as a swelling or a palpable mass, especially in the skull. Most commonly, they are located in the thoracic spine, followed by the skull and facial bones, followed by long bones where they preferentially involve the metaphysis or diaphysis.

 

 

Hemangioma of proximal femur

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma. Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin. Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly occur in patients of 10-30 years old. Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location. In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent. Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhea 2 weeks back, followed by swollen, red and erythematous joints. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shigella

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS/REITER’S SYNDROME

 

  • The patient presents with a classic picture of reactive arthritis. 

  • Reactive arthritis is precipitated by antecedent gastrointestinal and genitourinary infections and manifests as an asymmetric sterile oligoarthritis, typically of the lower extremities.

  • Reactive arthritis occurs most commonly in young men and is associated with HLA-B27 in 80% of patients.

  • Etiopathogenesis:

    • Most cases of reactive arthritis develop within 1-4 weeks after either a gastrointestinal infection (usually with Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, or Campylobacter) or a sexually transmitted infection (with Chlamydia trachomatis or perhaps Ureaplasma urealyticum).

  • Clinical Features:

    • The arthritis is most commonly asymmetric and frequently involves the large weight-bearing joints (chiefly the knee and ankle). 

    • Sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis is observed in at least 20% of patients, especially after frequent recurrences.

    • Triad: Arthritis + Conjunctivitis + Urethritis/Cervivitis (in females)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis, particularly in infants and young children. Typical symptoms among children with rotavirus infection include vomiting; watery, non-bloody diarrhea; and fever. In severe cases, dehydration, seizures, and death can occur. It is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option C. E.coli. While some strains of E. coli (like enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, and some E. coli infections have been linked to reactive arthritis, Shigella is more classically and frequently associated with it, especially given the history of fever and bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Giardia. Giardia is a parasite that causes giardiasis, characterized by watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, gas, and abdominal cramps. It is not typically associated with reactive arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis has been described following enteric infections with Giardia sp. The interval between the preceding infection and the manifestation of arthritis is 2-4 weeks.
