Post-infectious arthritis has a predilection for joints of the lower limbs particularly the knee and ankle. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella. 

  • This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema. 

  • It is commonly associated with HLA B27.

choices.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.
Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.
Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

 

  • The provided X-ray reveals a clearly defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma.
  • Additionally, the hyaline cap thickness of 2cms observed on the MRI raises concerns about the possibility of malignant transformation.

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is the developmental malformation thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap that is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs, a result of development malformation.
  • Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen which usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; has enlarged further after skeletal maturity, there is loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
  • In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick. (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad- based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common. The stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint. This is not true for an osteochondroma. The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap which is irregular and usually grows away from the growth plate.

 

Option B. Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential. This is not true. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses. Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place. It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick which can be best evaluated by MRI).

 

Option C. Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone. This is not true. The stalk of the lesion grows away from the physis, adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the corresponding components of the parent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: Identify the maneuver being performed in the given image? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Head tilt, chin lift

 

The maneuver performed in the given image is that of a head-tilt chin-lift. It is an important technique in emergency airway management to open up the airway.

 

  • Tilt the patient’s head back by pushing down on the forehead.
  • Place the tips of your index and middle fingers under the chin and pull up on the mandible (not on the soft tissues). This lifts the tongue away from the posterior pharynx and improves airway patency.

 

There is no absolute contraindication to it but Suspected cervical injury is a relative contraindication.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jaw thrust: Lift the mandible upward with your fingers, at least until the lower incisors are higher than the upper incisors. This maneuver lifts the tongue along with the mandible, thus relieving upper airway obstruction.

 

 

Option D. Manual inline stabilization: is a neck immobilisation technique in a natural position achieved by using the fingers and palms of both hands to stabilize the patient's occiput and mastoid processes to gently counteract the forces of airway intervention

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The head-tilt chin-lift maneuver is a key technique for opening the airway in emergency situations, especially when cervical spine injury is not suspected.

questions.text: Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and impinging on: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral component during extension

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • It is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).
  • Patients complain of a clunking during knee extension, caused by a suprapatellar fibrous nodule that interferes with patella movement.
  • There is an accumulation of scar tissue along the undersurface of the quadriceps tendon, proximal to the superior pole of the patella.
  • The cause of scar tissue is unknown, but may be related to:
    • Direct trauma to quadriceps tendon during patella resection during TKR
    • Impingement of the quadriceps tendon on the femoral component due to an undersized patellar component
  • Scar is entrapped within the intercondylar notch during flexion.
  • It impinges on the femoral component and is forced out of the notch during active knee extension.
  • The painful snap or clunk is usually felt between 30-45 degrees
  • Many patients can be managed without surgery.
  • However, if there are persistent symptoms, surgical excision of the nodule can be useful.

 

OTHER SOFT TISSUE DISORDERS

 

  • Irritation of the lateral facet of the patella: Contact between the lateral facet of the patella and the femoral implant, in the region of the lateral condyle, can cause chronic lateral knee pain.
  • Popliteal Tendon Impingement: After TKA, the popliteal tendon can be irritated by overhand of the femoral condyles, from a posterolateral osteophyte, from residual synovium or extruded cement. Patients complain of discrete posterior knee pain that occurs after a specific point of knee flexion.
  • Protruding Medial Tibial Component: Pain along the medial knee can be from the protrusion of the tibial, including medial collateral ligament irritation. Tibial revision is necessary if pain is intolerable.
  • Nerve Injury: Deep peroneal nerve injury is a rare but reported complication of TKA, caused by compression, ischemia, traction, crush, or laceration. It typically occurs when there is surgical correction of a significant preoperative valgus deformity or flexion contracture of the knee. The infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve (IBSN) is commonly affected after knee replacement. Patients can report numbness (sometimes a painful numbness) along the lateral aspect of the knee for over a year.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome is a very rare consequence of knee replacement. It is characterized by pain disproportionate to exam findings. There is sensory disturbance (e.g., pain evoked by light brushing of the skin, called allodynia), motor impairment (e.g., weakness), and sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., edema, color changes).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The scar of the patellar clunk syndrome after TKR is present at the superior pole of the patella and it impinges on the femoral component of the implant of active knee extension.

questions.text: What is the most sensitive investigation for parathyroid tumor imaging?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tc Sestamibi SPECT

 

Explanation:

 

For the imaging of parathyroid tumors, particularly in the context of hyperparathyroidism, several modalities can be employed. Each has its strengths and particular clinical situations where it might be the preferred choice.

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT (Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography technique also utilizes Technetium-99m sestamibi but combines it with CT imaging to provide three-dimensional imaging. This makes SPECT more sensitive than a plain sestamibi scan for locating parathyroid tumors, especially when they are ectopic or embedded deep within the neck or chest.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tc Sestamibi Scan: This is a nuclear medicine scan that uses a small amount of a radioactive compound , typically Technetium-99m sestamibi, which is absorbed by active parathyroid tissue more than normal tissue. While sensitive, it provides a two-dimensional view which can sometimes make precise localization of smaller or deeper tumors challenging.

 

Option C. USG (Ultrasound): Ultrasound is useful for imaging the parathyroid glands due to its non-invasive nature and ability to detect lesions in real-time. It is particularly effective for glands located in typical positions near the thyroid. However, its effectiveness diminishes for ectopic glands or in obese patients where acoustic windows may be poor.

 

Option D. MRI (Magnetic Resonance Imaging): MRI can provide detailed images and is useful in complex cases, such as when other imaging modalities fail or in surgical planning. However, its sensitivity is generally lower than Sestamibi SPECT for detecting parathyroid adenomas, and it is less commonly used primarily due to higher costs and limited availability.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tc Sestamibi SPECT is generally considered the most sensitive imaging modality for detecting parathyroid tumors, particularly because it offers three-dimensional localization capabilities that can greatly assist surgeons in planning minimally invasive surgery.

questions.text: Double bleb sign seen in early pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Yolk sac and amniotic sac

 

Explanation:

 

The double bleb sign is due to the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

On USG, gestational sac contains the yolk sac and amniotic sac which appear as two small bubbles known as the double bleb sign.

 

It is seen at 7.5 – 8 weeks.

 

Do not confuse with Double decidual sign

 

 

Double decidual sign – true gestational sac surrounded by two layers – decidua capsularis and decidua parietalis with fluid collection in between.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Twin pregnancy: This would involve two separate gestational sacs or distinct embryonic structures in a single sac, not the double bleb sign of a single gestational sac.

 

Option B. Amnion and chorion: These are two layers surrounding the embryo, but the double bleb sign specifically refers to the early visualization of the yolk sac and amniotic sac.

 

Option D. Heterotopic pregnancy: Involves simultaneous intrauterine and extrauterine pregnancies. This would not specifically relate to the double bleb sign, which is a normal ultrasound finding in a single intrauterine pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The double bleb sign is a normal ultrasound finding in early pregnancy, showing the presence of both the yolk sac and the amniotic sac within the gestational sac, important for confirming a normal early intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: A child presented with a history of road traffic accident. The axial CT image of the child is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extradural hemorrhage

 

Explanation:

 

The CT image shows a right-sided hyperdense area indicative of an acute extradural hemorrhage (EDH). Extradural hemorrhages typically result from high-energy trauma, such as a road traffic accident, and are often arterial in origin, frequently involving the middle meningeal artery (MMA). The classic biconvex or "lens-shaped" appearance, as observed, does not cross sutures but may cross the midline, distinguishing it from other types of hemorrhages.

 

Right sided hyperdense acute EDH is shown in the NCCT

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Subdural Hemorrhage: Typically presents with a crescentic or "banana-shaped" appearance, crosses sutures, and involves bridging veins, usually from lower energy trauma or trivial injuries, which is not compatible with the findings on this CT.

 

Option C. Subarachnoid Hemorrhage: Involves bleeding into the subarachnoid space, generally producing a diffuse or layered appearance in the CT, which is not evident here.

 

Option D. Intraventricular Hemorrhage: Results in blood within the ventricular system, showing up as hyperdense within the ventricles, not applicable to this case.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

A. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

 

 

B. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.

 

C. Anterior: In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.

 

D. Posterior: This is the least common type. In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common > central type > anterior type > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).
  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of  neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Psoas abscess can give rise to pseudo-hip flexion deformity
  • Paraplegia occurs most often in upper thoracic region.∙
  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • Sequelae of TB spine is usually bony ankylosis.

 

  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph: 
    • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: 
    • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
       
  • MRI:
    • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
    • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

  • Biopsy:
    • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

 

  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: no neural complaint; increased reflexes
    • Stage 2: weakness but can walk with support
    • Stage 3: non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%
    • Stage 4: bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%
       
       
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exists  then, surgery needs to be done.
    • Stage-wise Treatment:
      • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
      • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
      • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
      • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
         
    • ATT: 
      • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
      • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
         
    • Indications of surgery: 
      • Bowel bladder involvement
      • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
      • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
         
  • Surgical options for most of the cases aren anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed)

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
     

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.

choices.text: Adenylyl cyclase
Guanylyl cyclase
Phospholipase C

questions.text: Beta 2 receptor action leading to hyperglycemia/ hypoglycemia is mediated by which of the following enzymes? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adenylyl cyclase

 

Explanation

 

Beta 2 receptor action leading to hypoglycemia/ hyperglycemia is mediated by adenylyl cyclase.

 

Catecholamines act through beta 2 receptors and they use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system to stimulate the target tissues.

 

Cyclic AMP is synthesized from ATP by the action of the enzyme adenylyl cyclase.

 

  • Binding of the hormone to its receptor activates a G protein which, in turn, activates adenylyl cyclase
  • The resulting rise in cAMP turns on the appropriate response in the cell by either (or both):
    • Changing the molecular activities in the cytosol, often using Protein Kinase A (PKA) — a cAMP-dependent protein kinase that phosphorylates target proteins
    • Turning on a new pattern of gene transcription

 

Cyclic AMP produces one or more of the following responses:

 

  1. Contraction and relaxation of muscle fibers
  2. Alteration in the permeability of cell membrane
  3. Synthesis of substances inside the cell
  4. Secretion or release of substances by target cell
  5. Other physiological activities of the target cell

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guanylyl cyclase: Incorrect. While guanylyl cyclase also produces a cyclic nucleotide (cGMP) that acts as a second messenger, it is not involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor pathway.

 

Option C. Phospholipase C: Incorrect. Phospholipase C is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, not Gs-coupled receptors like the beta-2 receptors. It catalyzes the breakdown of phosphatidylinositol bisphosphate into diacylglycerol and inositol triphosphate, which are involved in calcium signaling.

 

Option D. Phospholipase A2: Incorrect. This enzyme liberates arachidonic acid from phospholipids, leading to the production of eicosanoids (like prostaglandins and leukotrienes). It is not directly involved in the beta-2 adrenergic receptor signaling pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Other hormones that use adenylyl cyclase - CAMP second messenger system are:

 

  • ACTH
  • Angiotensin II
  • Corticotropin-releasing hormone
  • Calcitonin
  • FSH
  • Glucagon
  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone
  • HCG
  • Luteinizing hormone
  • Parathyroid hormone
  • Secretin
  • Somatostatin
  • TSH
  • Vasopressin

choices.text: Stop the treatment and follow up
Continue treatment for another 2 years
Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment
Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics

questions.text: A 16-year-old who is taking antiepileptics, has had a seizure-free period of 6 months. She has no family history of epilepsy. Her EEG is now normal and she has a normal neurological exam and intelligence. What would be your advice? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Continue treatment for another 2 years

 

In cases of epilepsy, particularly in children and adolescents, the continuation of antiepileptic drug (AED) therapy after a period of being seizure-free is typically recommended for about 2 years. This recommendation is based on the need to stabilize neurological function and minimize the risk of recurrence. The decision to discontinue AEDs should consider factors such as the duration of being seizure-free, EEG findings, the type of epilepsy, and the individual’s neurological examination.

 

Rationale for Continuing Treatment:

 

  • Continuing AED treatment for at least 2 years after achieving seizure control helps ensure the stability of the condition and reduces the likelihood of seizure recurrence, especially during the critical developmental years of adolescence.
  • Recurrences are most common in the first 3 months after discontinuing AEDs, making a cautious approach necessary.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop the treatment and follow up: This would be risky given the short period of seizure freedom (only 6 months). Stopping treatment prematurely may lead to recurrence.

 

Option C. Gradually taper the drug and stop treatment: This is typically considered after a longer period of seizure freedom, usually a minimum of 2 years, not just 6 months.

 

Option D. Continue lifelong treatment with antiepileptics: This is generally reserved for cases of refractory epilepsy where seizures cannot be controlled with multiple medications, which does not seem to be the case here based on the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anti-epileptics once initiated must be continued for a minimum period of 2 years. Decision to stop AED is considered if, seizure free > 2 years with normal MRI, EEG, seizure type.

 

Recurrences occur in the first 3 months of discontinuing AED.

 

Reference - Harrison principles of internal Medicine 21st edition Pg. 12076

questions.text: Which of the following physiological adaptations is generally not observed at high altitudes? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Respiratory acidosis

 

The physiological adaptation that does not happen at high altitudes is respiratory acidosis. Respiratory alkalosis is the physiological adaptation seen at high altitudes due to hyperventilation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary vasoconstriction: Correct, as it is a physiological response to low oxygen levels to improve gas exchange.

 

Option B. Polycythemia: Correct, as it increases the blood's oxygen-carrying capacity.

 

Option D. Hypoxia: Correct, as it is the primary condition caused by low oxygen levels at high altitudes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The principal means by which acclimatization to high altitude comes about are

 

  1. A great increase in pulmonary ventilation - increase in pulmonary ventilation on rising to a high altitude blows off large quantities of carbon dioxide, reducing the Pco2 and increasing the ph of the body fluids.
  2. Increased numbers of red blood cells,
  3. Increased diffusing capacity of the lungs,
  4. Increased vascularity of the peripheral tissues
  5. Increased ability of the tissue cells to use oxygen despite low Po2.
  6. Cellular Acclimatization - cell mitochondria and cellular oxidative enzyme systems are slightly more plentiful than in sea-level inhabitants

questions.text: Identify the fracture site in the X-ray shown below. (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 4th, 5th, 6th rib

 

The given X-ray shows the fracture of the 4th, 5th, 6th rib.

 

 

Tricks to counting ribs:

 

  • The horizontal oriented ribs are posterior ribs
  • The oblique oriented ribs are anterior ribs
  • Count below from 1st rib one after another

 

Counting ribs on a chest X-ray in the posteroanterior (PA) view can be done by locating the clavicle and 1st rib. Count downward from the first rib as you move along.

 

 

Differentiating between posterior and anterior ribs on an X-ray can be done by looking at direction of the Rib Curvature. On a posterior-anterior (PA) chest X-ray, anterior ribs typically exhibit a downward convex curvature as they wrap around the chest wall. In contrast, the posterior ribs have an upward concave curvature as they extend posteriorly towards the spine.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

When identifying rib fractures on a chest X-ray, start counting from the first rib, which is located just beneath the clavicle, and follow downward. Note the curvature of the ribs: anterior ribs curve downward and outward, while posterior ribs curve upward. This method helps in accurately locating and identifying the specific ribs involved in fractures or other abnormalities.

questions.text: A TPN bag consists of 100g glucose, 30g amino acids, and 40g lipids. What is the amount of calories delivered? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 880 Kcal

 

In patients who cannot (unconscious; removal of large part of gut) or should not (major trauma or surgery) use their gastrointestinal tract, total parenteral feeding has to be resorted. The solution may be infused through one of the large vessels like subclavian vein or superior vena cava, where the blood flow is sufficient to dilute the hypertonic solution. This procedure is known as total parenteral nutrition (TPN) or intravenous hyperalimentation.

 

The number of calories delivered by the given TPN (Total Parenteral Nutrition) bag is 880 Kcal.

 

The caloric values of different food components are:

• Carbohydrate (glucose) - 4KCal/g

• Proteins (amino acids) - 4.2KCal/g = ~4KCal/g

• Fat (lipids) - 9Kcal/g

 

Calculation of the number of calories:

• 100 gm of glucose = 100 × 4 KCal=400 KCal

• 30 gm of amino acids = 30 × 4 KCal= 120 KCal

• 40 gm of lipids = 40 × 9 KCal= 360 KCal

Total amount of calories delivered= 400+120+360=880 Kcal

 

Note: The caloric value of alcohol is 7KCal/g.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total Parenteral Nutrition (TPN) is a method used to deliver nutrients directly into the bloodstream when patients cannot use their gastrointestinal tract. The caloric value of the nutrients provided in the TPN bag can be calculated based on the caloric content of carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

 

Caloric Values:

 

  • Carbohydrates (glucose): 4 KCal/g
  • Proteins (amino acids): Approximately 4 KCal/g
  • Fats (lipids): 9 KCal/g

questions.text: During rounds, your senior was discussing the given image. The following is an image of which of the following investigations? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CT scan

 

Explanation:  

 

The above given image is a CT scan image since the bone can be identified as a high-density structure which appears white.

 

CT scan is an imaging modality which uses X-rays for cross sectional images of the body and the density of the tissue through which this x-ray beam passes is measured from the calculation of attenuation coefficient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Contrast Dye study: While contrast may be used in CT scans, the term "contrast dye study" alone does not specifically indicate a CT scan.

 

Option B. X-ray: Typically provides two-dimensional imaging and lacks the cross-sectional detail shown in these images.

 

Option C. D Angiography: Focuses on blood vessels using contrast material and typically does not provide detailed images of other anatomical structures as seen in these scans.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CT scans are invaluable in medical imaging for providing detailed cross-sectional views of internal structures, utilizing X-ray technology to distinguish between different tissue densities, evident from the white appearance of bone and detailed soft tissue visualization in the images.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female patient is brought to the ER in a state of unconsciousness. Her BP is 70/50 mm of Hg and her ECG is shown below. What is the next best step in the management of her condition? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Synchronized cardioversion

 

Any hemodynamically unstable rhythm, requires synchronized cardioversion (Shock delivered in sync with R wave to prevent R-on-T phenomenon)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: AV Nodal blockers are used if hemodynamically stable.

 

Option B: Maximum of 30mg of adenosine can be tried if patient is Hemodynamically Stable.

 

Option C: Carotid massage is not recommended for hemodynamically unstable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the likely cause of a disease that is characterized by the occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Drugs

 

Adverse drug reactions can lead to a condition known as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or its more severe form, Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN), where there is extensive detachment of the epidermis and mucous membrane involvement. This severe reaction typically involves over 30% of the body surface area in TEN. It is a medical emergency and can be life-threatening. The implicated drugs often include allopurinol, certain anticonvulsants, sulphonamide antibiotics, and NSAIDs, among others.

 

As more than 30% of the body surface is involved, the diagnosis is toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). Clinical picture will be as shown in the image below.

 

 

SJS Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis classification based on BSA involvement:

 

Based on body surface area (BSA):  

 

 

SJS/TEN is primarily a drug‐induced phenomenon, with a culprit drug being demonstrated in approximately 85% of cases.

 

Common drugs that can cause SJS/TEN are:

 

  • Allopurinol
  • Carbamazepine
  • Lamotrigine
  • Nevirapine
  • Oxicam (Non‐steroidal anti‐inflammatory drugs)
  • Phenobarbital
  • Phenytoin
  • Sulfamethoxazole and other sulfa antibiotics
  • Sulfasalazine

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral Infection: Viral infections can indeed cause skin rashes and even blistering in some cases, such as with herpes viruses, including Varicella-zoster virus and Herpes simplex virus. However, they rarely lead to a condition with widespread blistering affecting over 30% of the body surface area.

 

Option C. Fungal Infection: Fungal infections typically cause localized skin changes such as rashes, scaling, and sometimes blistering, but these are usually limited in scope and do not affect such a large proportion of the skin surface as described in the scenario.

 

Option D. Auto-immunity: Autoimmune diseases like pemphigus vulgaris can cause blistering, but they do not usually result in acute widespread skin peeling over 30% of the body surface area. The blisters in pemphigus vulgaris are more superficial and often rupture easily, not typically resulting in extensive peeling.

 

In conclusion, when presented with widespread blistering and peeling of such a significant portion of the skin, drug reactions should be the first consideration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The occurrence of blistering and peeling affecting over 30% of the body surface area is most commonly associated with severe drug reactions, such as Stevens-Johnson Syndrome (SJS) or Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis (TEN).

 

Ref - Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition, Chapter 119, Page no 119.13

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

questions.text: All of the options listed can be utilized for assessing data normalcy except? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Mantel-Haenszel test

 

  • The Mantel Haenszel test is used for sample sets that are able to be placed in two by two tables, but unlike the Fisher Exact test and the chi-squared test, there is no “n” requirement.
  • Normality of a data refers to a specific statistical distribution called a normal distribution, or sometimes the Gaussian distribution or bell-shaped curve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plot histogram: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A histogram can visually show whether data follow a normal distribution.

 

Option C. Box whisker: Correct for assessing data normalcy. A box-and-whisker plot (box plot) can reveal the symmetry and spread of data, indicating normality.

 

Option D. Shapiro Wilk test: Correct for assessing data normalcy. The Shapiro-Wilk test is a statistical test specifically designed to test the normality of data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Mantel-Haenszel test is not used for assessing the normality of data. Normality can be assessed using tools like plot histograms, box-and-whisker plots, Shapiro-Wilk test, Kolmogorov–Smirnov test, etc.

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign on MRI is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Arachnoiditis

 

Explanation:

 

The empty thecal sac sign, which appears on MRI as an apparent absence or clumping of the nerve roots within the thecal sac, is indicative of arachnoiditis. Arachnoiditis is an inflammation of the arachnoid linings of the spinal canal, which can cause the nerve roots to clump together and adhere to one another or the lining of the canal, leaving the thecal sac appearing empty or devoid of its normal content of floating nerve roots.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Discitis: An inflammation of the intervertebral disc, which would not typically show the empty thecal sac sign but might show disc space narrowing and endplate erosions.

 

Option C. Vertebral osteomyelitis: An infection of the vertebral bodies, generally presenting with bony destruction, soft tissue swelling, and possibly an abscess but not the empty thecal sac sign.

 

Option D. Tethered cord syndrome: Characterized by an abnormally low conus medullaris with associated thickened filum terminale, not typically associated with the empty thecal sac sign.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRI of Arachnoiditis shows Empty thecal sac sign.

Due to inflammation, nerve roots are clumped and empty thecal sac are seen on MRI of the lumbar spine.

questions.text: The following groups of people must be screened for Ca cervix: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25 to 65-year-old females

 

Explanation:

 

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines (2020), cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years. The guidelines specify the following:

 

ACOG/ACS Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 25.
  • Ages 25 to 65:
    • HPV testing every 5 years (preferred).
    • HPV/Pap co-testing every 5 years (acceptable).
    • Pap test alone every 3 years (acceptable).
  • Age >65: No testing required if a series of previous tests were normal.

 

WHO Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 30.
  • Primary mode of screening: HPV testing.
  • Frequency: Every 5 to 10 years.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. More than 65 years old: Screening is generally not required for women over 65 if they have had a series of normal screening results.

 

Option B. Less than 25 years old: Screening is not recommended for women under 25 according to ACOG/ACS guidelines.

 

Option D. Teenagers: Screening is not recommended for teenagers as cervical cancer is extremely rare in this age group and the benefits of screening do not outweigh the potential harms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years, with various acceptable methods and intervals as specified by the ACOG and ACS guidelines.

 

Ref: ACOG guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, WHO guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 634, 635.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding investigation of malignant bone tumors? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Always done by transverse incision.
  2. Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  3. Sample should be taken before any radiological investigations.
  4. Sample should be taken from periphery and not from necrotic centre.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor. 

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone and the most frequent cause of pathologic fractures in children.
  • Bone cysts usually affect patients between 5 and 15 years of age and occur more often in boys than in girls (2:1).
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%. The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • It is more common in males than in females with a peak incidence in the second decade of life.
  • Although it may be present in almost any bone, the proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and  it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive.
    • A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve.
    • If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10–15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • Incidence is Males > Females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a first-line drug for the management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Azathioprine

 

The first-line drugs for the management of rheumatoid arthritis (RA) are typically Disease-Modifying Antirheumatic Drugs (DMARDs), which include sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate. These drugs are considered core therapies and are often used together in what is known as "triple therapy."

 

Sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate are highly effective and commonly used in the treatment of RA. They form the backbone of conventional synthetic DMARDs (csDMARDs).

 

Azathioprine, on the other hand, is not a first-line drug for RA management. While it is used in some autoimmune conditions, it is not as effective for RA as the other mentioned drugs. Its efficacy is lower, and it is not commonly included in the standard RA treatment regimens.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulfasalazine: This drug is a part of the core therapies for RA and is commonly used as a first-line treatment. It is known for its effectiveness and is often used in combination with other DMARDs.

 

Option B. Hydroxychloroquine: Another key first-line drug for RA, hydroxychloroquine is widely used due to its efficacy and relatively favorable safety profile. It is often part of the triple therapy regimen.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Methotrexate is considered the cornerstone of RA treatment and is usually the first drug prescribed. It is highly effective and forms the basis of most RA treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Azathioprine is not a first-line drug for the management of rheumatoid arthritis; the primary first-line drugs are sulfasalazine, hydroxychloroquine, and methotrexate.

 

Note -

 

  • Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine are considered safe for use during pregnancy and are preferred in the management of RA among pregnant patients.
  • Azathioprine is also somewhat safe during pregnancy, but it is not as effective for RA, so it is less preferred compared to Sulfasalazine and Hydroxychloroquine.
  • Methotrexate and Leflunomide are not safe for use during pregnancy and should be avoided due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Additional Information:

 

Rheumatoid arthritis management: Range of biological disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (bDMARDs) and targeted synthetic disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (tsDMARDs).

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from the nose, nasal obstruction and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red polypoidal mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image what would be the diagnosis of this patient? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rhinosporidiosis

Rhinosporidiosis is a chronic infection caused by the aquatic organism Rhinosporidium seeberi. It primarily affects mucous membranes, especially in the nasal passages but also the eyes, ears, and occasionally other areas. Patients typically present with polypoidal masses in the nasal area that can cause bleeding, nasal obstruction, and respiratory difficulty. It is commonly associated with exposure to stagnant water.

Histopathology: Characteristic findings include large, thick-walled sporangia containing numerous endospores, as observed in the provided histopathological image.

Other Options: 

Option B. Basal Cell Carcinoma

Basal cell carcinoma is a type of skin cancer that commonly appears on sun-exposed areas but can occasionally occur near the nasal region. It typically presents as a nodular lesion with a pearly edge and may have telangiectasias but lacks the distinct histopathology of sporangia with endospores.

Histopathology: Microscopically, it shows nests of basaloid cells with palisading nuclei at the periphery.

 

Option C. Rhinoscleroma

Rhinoscleroma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis, affecting the respiratory tract. It leads to the formation of hard, sclerotic nodules and masses mainly in the nasal passages.

Histopathology: It is characterized by the presence of Mikulicz cells, which are large foam cells containing the bacteria, and a background of chronic inflammatory cells.

Option D. Lupus Vulgaris

Lupus vulgaris is a form of cutaneous tuberculosis presenting typically on the skin with reddish-brown nodules and plaques that can ulcerate over time. It rarely affects the nasal area directly unless there is disseminated cutaneous involvement.

Histopathology: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis typical of tuberculosis.

Educational Objective:

Rhinosporidiosis should be suspected in patients with nasal masses who have a history of contact with stagnant water bodies, presenting with the characteristic polypoidal mass and sporangia on histopathology.

questions.text: A person often feels that his hands are contaminated and he is forced to wash his hands. Recently, he feels this repetitive, distressing thought of repetitive hand washing has begun affecting his performance. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Exposure and response prevention

 

The patient's symptoms are consistent with Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD). One of the most effective treatments for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), which is a type of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) specific for OCD.

 

Exposure and response prevention is the mainstay treatment for OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DBT (Dialectical Behavior Therapy): DBT is primarily used for borderline personality disorder and other self-harming behaviors.

 

Option C. Systematic desensitization: Systematic desensitization is a behavioral technique mainly used to treat phobias by gradually exposing the patient to the phobic stimulus.

 

Option D. CBT (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy): CBT is a broader therapeutic technique and is used in a variety of psychiatric disorders.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For OCD, Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of CBT, is the evidence-based first-line treatment. It involves exposing patients to their obsessional triggers while refraining from performing their compulsive rituals, gradually reducing the distress elicited by obsessions.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 425.

questions.text: What is the origin of the fibers marked by the arrow? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above image is the cross-section of the human brain in which the marked arrow indicates the fornix.
  • Fornix belongs to projectional fibers which are the type of white matter fibers. Fornix forms the efferent fibers of the hippocampus and connects it with the mammillary body. Hence the origin of fibers is hippocampus
  • The fornix is a white matter bundle located in the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres which arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.
  • It connects various nodes of a limbic circuitry and is believed to play a key role in cognition and episodic memory recall.
  • Fornix is an example of association fiber and is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • The hippocampus is a seahorse-shaped structure located within the temporal lobes of the brain. The fornix originates from the hippocampus. Specifically, it receives input from the hippocampus and sends axons that project back to the hippocampus. This loop of connections is involved in memory formation and retrieval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Habenular: The habenular nuclei are small structures located near the thalamus and are involved in various functions, including the regulation of the pineal gland's activity. The fornix is not directly associated with the habenular nuclei. Instead, it primarily connects the hippocampus to other structures in the limbic system.

 

Option C. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain. The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies. This connection is an essential component of the Papez circuit, a neural circuit involved in memory and emotion.

 

Option D. Amygdala: The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes and plays a key role in processing emotions, particularly fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala is part of the limbic system, it is not directly connected to the fornix. Instead, the amygdala communicates with other limbic structures through various neural pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is useful for a patient having Haemophilia B?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fresh frozen plasma

 

Haemophilia B is characterized by a deficiency in factor IX. The treatment for haemophilia B focuses on supplementing the deficient factor IX. Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) is an excellent source of factor IX and is therefore useful in treating haemophilia B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cryoprecipitate: Incorrect. Cryoprecipitate is rich in factor VIII and is primarily used for treating haemophilia A, not haemophilia B.

 

Option C. Recombinant factor 8: Incorrect. Recombinant factor VIII is used to treat haemophilia A, which is a deficiency in factor VIII, not factor IX.

 

Option D. Cryo poor plasma: Incorrect. Although cryo poor plasma can still contain some factor IX, it is not the best choice compared to fresh frozen plasma. Cryo poor plasma is more commonly used for treating thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia B is a genetic deficiency of Factor IX, also called Christmas disease.

 

It is an X-linked recessive bleeding disorder, causing:

 

  • Easy bruising
  • Hemarthroses
  • Prolonged bleeding after injury or surgery

 

For the treatment of haemophilia B, fresh frozen plasma is an effective source of factor IX. Recombinant factor IX would be the best treatment option if available.

questions.text: You have been called to declare the brain death of a 12-year-old child in the ICU. Which of the following is not seen in brain death? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Decorticate and decerebrate posturing

 

Brain death is defined as the irreversible cessation of all brain activity, including the brainstem. It is a clinical diagnosis based on the absence of neurological function and the irreversible loss of the capacity for consciousness and spontaneous respiration.

 

In brain death, the following clinical observations can be present and may be mistakenly interpreted as signs of brainstem function, but they do not indicate any meaningful brain activity:

 

Things That Can Be Present in Brain Death- 

  1. Normal blood pressure without drugs
  2. Spinal reflexes
    1. Movements like Babinski, deep tendon reflexes may be seen.
    2. These come from the spinal cord, not the brain
  3. Sweating or tachycardia
    1. Autonomic responses — do not indicate brain activity.
  4. What is Not Seen in Brain Death:
    1. Decorticate or decerebrate posturing
      1. These need some brain activity
      2. In brain death: no such posturing happens — total motor silence.


         

 

However, decorticate and decerebrate posturing are not seen in brain death. These postures are indicative of severe brain injury but require some level of brain activity to generate the motor response. In brain death, all brain-originating motor responses, including these postures, are absent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal BP without pharmacological support: Autonomic responses may still maintain blood pressure without brain function, making this observation consistent with brain death.

 

Option B. Positive spinal reflexes on stimulation: These reflexes are mediated by the spinal cord, not the brain, and thus can still occur in brain death.

 

Option C. Sweating and tachycardia: These autonomic functions can persist despite brain death due to residual autonomic nervous system activity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brain death is characterized by the complete absence of brain-originating motor responses, including decorticate and decerebrate posturing, despite possible preservation of autonomic functions like normal BP and spinal reflexes.

choices.text: High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: The dead body of a 4-year-old child who was playing around the riverside and accidentally drowned in the river is recovered. There is frothing seen from his mouth and nose. Which of the below postmortem findings is not seen in a case of drowning? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. High concentration of arsenic from shaft of hair

 

The image shows frothing from nostrils which is likely to be due to antemortem drowning.

 

This finding is unrelated to drowning and would suggest chronic arsenic poisoning rather than an acute drowning incident.

 

Postmortem changes of drowning:

 

  • Bloody froth in the airway
  • Water in the stomach and small intestine
  • Water in middle ear
  • Cerebral edema
  • Bloated and cyanosed face
  • Petrous or mastoid hemorrhage.
  • Voluminous / ballooned out lungs
  • Suffused conjunctive, dilated pupils
  • "Washerwoman" changes of the hands (shriveling of the skin) develop when submerged in water for several hours
  • Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist 
  • Cutis anserina / goose skin- The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and a grainy appearance of the skin.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Diatom test

 

Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voluminous and ballooned out lungs: Seen in drowning due to the inhalation of water.

 

Option C. Paltauf's hemorrhage in sub pleura: Hemorrhages found beneath the pleura, associated with drowning.

 

Option D. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: Indicates a struggle and is a sign of antemortem drowning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of drowning, typical findings include frothing from the mouth and nose, voluminous lungs, and cadaveric spasm with debris. High arsenic concentration in hair shafts is not associated with drowning.

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shin splint

 

STRESS/FATIGUE FRACTURE

 

  • Stress fracture is due to imbalance between load and resistance of bone.
  • It is of 2 types:
    1. Fatigue fracture: Caused by application of abnormal stress on normal bone.
    2. Insufficiency fracture: Caused by normal activity on weak bone.
  • Sites of Stress Fractures:
    1. Lower Extremity:
      • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck. The most common site is metatarsal neck followed by tibia (proximal third in children, middle third in athlete and lower third in elderly).
      • Tibia stress fracture = Shin splints
      • Femoral neck (inferomedial compression side in young and superior tension side in older patients).
      • Rarely fibula lower end (runner’s fracture).
    2. Upper Extremity:
      • Olecranon is most common site of upper limb stress fractures.
    3. Pelvis and Spine:
      • Pars interarticularis of 5th lumbar vertebral (causing spondylolysis) is commonest in spine.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Load related pain often bilateral
    • The hallmark physical finding is tenderness with palpation and stress.
  • Investigation:
    • MRI provides excellent sensitivity and superior specificity compared to bone scan in differentiating from infections or tumors.
    • Bone scan is preferable for bilateral cases due to feasibility, also bilateral cases go in favour of stress fracture as compared to Infection or tumor and also can scan the whole body.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic with cast and cessation of activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lisfranc fracture. A Lisfranc dislocation is a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot. The Lisfranc joint is composed of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones, and the cuneiform bones. Injury of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement. Lisfranc injuries are uncommon and are often misdiagnosed. Even when recognized and treated promptly, there is still a high risk for chronic disability and complications. There are two main mechanisms of injury: direct, and indirect. A direct mechanism occurs as a crush injury to the joint from motor vehicle collision or industrial accident. An indirect injury is more common and is often associated with sports participation involving a longitudinal force with the foot in plantarflexion with a medial or lateral rotational force. The patient presents with complaint of midfoot pain with weight-bearing, following an acute injury. The pain worsens by forefoot weight bearing, and the patient may describe pain or difficulty with the push-off phases of walking and/or running. There is pain with abduction and eversion of the forefoot. Pain can also commonly be reproduced with passive pronation or supination of the tarsometatarsal joint. Radiographic findings show misalignment of the lateral margin of the first metatarsal base with the lateral edge of the medial cuneiform, misalignment of the medial aspect of the second metatarsal base with the medial edge of the middle cuneiform, and/or small avulsion fragments a one of metatarsal or cuneiform bones. On oblique view, the medial aspect of the cuboid should line up with the medial aspect of the fourth metatarsal base. The dorsal cortex of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform should be aligned on the lateral radiographs. Lisfranc injuries can be managed operatively. Initial treatment includes reduction, splinting, and elevation. After six weeks, if the patient is non-tender and radiographs are negative, then begin weight-bearing and rehabilitation. If there is any tenderness but no displacement, then the patient should be in a boot or cast for at least another four weeks before starting rehabilitation. Any displacement requires surgical fixation.

 

 

Option B. Jones fracture. A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation. The fracture occurs as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion. On a plain radiograph, Jones fracture is located at the metadiaphyseal junction, approximately 2 cm (1.5-3 cm) from the tip of the 5th metatarsal and has a predominantly horizontal course. It should not extend distally. Jones fractures are particularly prone to non-union due to being in a vascular watershed zone and take longer than two months to heal. Displacement of the fracture can increase with persistent weight-bearing; therefore, immobilization is important, with a non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks. Indications for non-operative management include undisplaced fractures and fractures in patients with limited activity (i.e. recreational athletes). Operative management is indicated in patients that are elite or competitive athletes or when delayed union has occurred. Management includes either intramedullary screw fixation or open reduction and internal fixation. 

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker fracture. A nutcracker fracture refers to a cuboid bone fracture with associated navicular avulsion fracture due to compression between the bases of 4th and 5th metatarsals and calcaneus bone. The injury usually occurs secondary to the traumatic abduction of the forefoot. This results in loss of the normal lateral column support and excess valgus force upon the medial column that commonly causes rupture of tibialis posterior tendon or avulsion fracture of its attachment onto medial aspect of the tarsal navicular bone. Nutcracker fractures are clinically significant because they can interfere with the medchanical alignment of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shint splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HTLV

 

  • HTLV - Human T cell lymphotropic virus causes microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.
  • Oncoviruses are classified as direct or indirect carcinogens, although some overlap exists between the distinction. Direct carcinogenic viruses possess viral oncogenes that directly contribute to neoplastic cellular transformation, whereas indirect carcinogens cause chronic inflammation, which can lead to oncogenic transformation.
  • DNA tumor viruses encode viral oncoproteins which may become integrated into the host cell chromosome.
  • RNA viruses are known to cause microbial carcinogenesis by indirect mechanisms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HPV (Human Papillomavirus):

 

  • Mechanism: HPV integrates its DNA into the host genome, leading to the production of oncoproteins E6 and E7, which inactivate tumor suppressor genes p53 and Rb. This disruption of tumor suppressor pathways contributes to the development of cancers such as cervical cancer.
  • Example: Cervical cancer is a well-documented outcome of HPV infection, particularly with high-risk strains like HPV 16 and 18.

 

Option B. HBV (Hepatitis B Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: HBV can integrate its DNA into the host genome, contributing to hepatocellular carcinoma. The integration can lead to genomic instability and the insertional activation of oncogenes or inactivation of tumor suppressor genes.
  • Example: Chronic hepatitis B infection is a major risk factor for hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Option D. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):

 

  • Mechanism: EBV can integrate into the host genome and produce latent proteins that drive cell proliferation and prevent apoptosis. The viral proteins LMP1 and EBNA2 are key players in this process, contributing to the development of various cancers, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, and nasopharyngeal carcinoma.
  • Example: EBV is strongly associated with Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in endemic areas such as sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:

 

  • Oncogenic DNA Viruses:
    • EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
    • HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
    • MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • Oncogenic RNA Viruses:
    • HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
    • HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with the history of cough for one week. He also gives a history of hemoptysis for 1 month and fever for 4 days. The X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. RML consolidation

 

Explanation:

 

The X-ray shown above indicates consolidation due to presence of opacities in the right middle lobe silhouetting the right heart border along with the history of fever, cough and hemoptysis.

 

Silhouette sign

 

 

  • When the markings of heart are not visible – silhouette sign positive – localized to middle lobe /lingula
  • When the markings of heart are visible – silhouette sign negative – localized to lower lobe.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RLL consolidation: Typically presents with obscuration of the right hemidiaphragm on X-ray, not the heart border.

 

Option C. RUL consolidation: Would more commonly show opacities in the upper right lung without affecting the silhouette of the heart.

 

Option D. Pericardial effusion: Would generally show an enlarged cardiac silhouette ("water bottle" sign), which is not evident in this image.

 

Educational Objective :

 

RML consolidation can be diagnosed when there is obscuration of the right heart border due to lung opacities in the middle lobe, accompanied by clinical symptoms of respiratory infection.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a severe headache is scheduled to undergo a CT scan. During history taking, which of the following will you definitely ask for before the commencement of the scan? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LMP

 

Explanation:

 

The most important information to obtain during a history in a 28-year-old woman of reproductive age who has been referred for a CT scan is the last menstrual period (LMP). Since it is imperative to rule out pregnancy before taking a CT scan, last menstrual period is the most appropriate answer to this question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Use of cochlear implant: While important in MRI to prevent damage to the implant from the magnetic field, it is not typically a concern in CT scans which use X-rays.

 

Option C. History of fall: Although relevant to the medical history, it is not critical specifically before a CT scan unless symptoms suggest complications that a CT scan could exacerbate.

 

Option D. History of hypertension: Important in overall patient assessment but does not directly influence the decision to perform a CT scan as critically as confirming pregnancy status does.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inquiring about the Last Menstrual Period (LMP) is essential for any woman of childbearing age before undergoing diagnostic procedures involving radiation, such as a CT scan, to avoid potential harm to an unborn baby.
